body:
To run the cifar10 example using the shared memory Hogwild, just configure the cluster.conf as
1. Do update at worker side with 2 worker groups
   nworker_groups: 2
   nserver_groups: 0
   nworkers_per_group: 1
   nworkers_per_procs: 2
   workspace: "examples/cifar10/" 
2. Or do update at the server side with 2 worker groups
   nworker_groups: 2
   nserver_groups: 1
   nservers_per_group:1
   nworkers_per_group: 1
   nworkers_per_procs: 2
   workspace: "examples/cifar10/"

To avoid frequent changes of the configuration files, cifar10 example's configuration files are renamed to cluster.conf.example and model.conf.example. Users are suggested to copy *.conf.example to *.conf to run the program. TODO add *.conf in .gitignore to ignore the cluster.conf and example.conf.

Previously, users has to call `sudo ./install.sh <software_name>`  to install the software into system's default lib folder. However, it is not necessary to extract the tar files and call `make` command with sudo right. Only make install requires sudo right. This pull request improves the install.sh script.
Now, if users do not provide the installation prefix, the install.sh script will call 

```
sudo make install ...
```

to install the software in system's default lib path. Otherwise it calls

```
make install...
```

to install the software in user specified PREFIX folder.

Another issue with the previous script is that if users call `sudo ./install.sh zookeeper`, then the zookeeper folder cannot be written by the ./bin/singa-run script without sudo right. Consequently, the zookeeper cannot be started successfully at run time.

4 more files reviewed:

singleton.h factory.h
  -- refine singleton to make it thread safe
  -- make factory functions inlined

cluster_rt.h, cluster_rt.cc
  -- change function name to follow coding style:
    \* sWatchSGroup -> WatchSGroup
    \* wJoinSGroup -> JoinSGroup
    \* wLeaveSGroup -> LeaveSGroup

A simple way to test this feature is to configure the server group with >1 servers in cluster.conf for cifar10 example:

```
nservers_per_group: 2
nservers_per_procs: 2
workspace: "examples/cifar10/"
```

The log will display how the parameters are sliced and partitioned into 2 servers.
But since server side is not the bottleneck of the training, increasing servers per group would not reduce the training time. This feature will be used in distributed hogwild training and allreduce training.

To run the distributed Hogwild framework, configure the cluster.conf as:

```
nworker_groups: 2
nserver_groups: 2
```

and start one process as,

```
./bin/singa-run.sh -model=... -cluster=...
```

and then start another process as,

```
./singa -model=... -cluster=...
```

Note that the two commands are different! The first one will start the zookeeper.
TODO, create a script to start multiple processes.

Many shared pointers are replaced with raw pointers to make the code tidy. 'shared_ptr' adds many characters that usually leads to two lines for one statement.

This pull request also cleans the API of Layer class:
- Setup(LayerProto, int npartitions), setup the layer's member data according to user specified configuration. If npartitions > 1, then this layer should be setup as one of npartitions sub-layers.
- ComputeFeature(Phase, Metric*), now the this function can be used for forward propagation of BP algorithm by passing Phase as kTrain or kForward in BPWorker; It can also be used for the positive phase of CD algorithm by passing Phase as kPositive. The Metric pointer is to collect performance information from this layer. E.g., the loss layers would add metric like loss or accuracy to it.
- ComputeGradient(Phase), the Phase argument is not used now (neither BP nor CD need this argument), but is added just in case some other algorithms may need it in the future.
- DebugString(int, Phase), this function is newly added to generate some debug information from one layer. The DebugInfo function of NeuralNet class is removed.
- ConnectionType dst_layer_connection(), return the connection type of this layer and all dst layers.
  Currently support two connections: kOneToOne and kOneToMany. kOneToOne indicates the users implement the ComputeFeature and ComputeGradient function considering only one dest layer. In this case, a SplitLayer will be added automatically to connect this layer with all dest layer. kOneToMany indicates the users has already considered multiple dest layers in the implementation. Hence no SplitLayer will be inserted.
- ConnectionType src_neuron_connection(int k)ï¼Œ return the connection type between one neuron of this layer and its source layer. Currently support two connection types: kOneToOne, and kOneToAll.
  kOneToOne indicates the neuron depends on only one neuron from src layer. kOneToAll indicates the neuron depends on all neurons from src layer. param k is the index of source layer (current only support k = 0).

The Metric Class is updated to use Google Protocol buffer as the serialization tool.
- ToLogString() will print a human readable string, which would be used for logging.
- ToString() will serialize the metric object into binary string for transmission.

Now the metrics is collected from every layer's ComputeFeature function. Hence the Worker does not need to explicitly collecting metrics from loss layers.
Pull request cancelled.

For the  cifar10 example, if we configure the model.conf as:

```
...
checkpoint_after: 100
checkpoint_frequency: 300
...
```

Then after training for 700 steps, under cifar10/checkpoint folder, there would be two checkpoint files:

```
step400-worker0.bin
step700-worker0.bin
```

We can resume the training from the last checkpoint (i.e., step 700) by:

```
./bin/singa-run.sh -conf=examples/cifar10 -resume=true
```

We can also use the the snapshot from step 400 as the pre-trained model for a new model by configuring the model.conf of the new model as:

```
...
checkpoint : examples/cifar10/checkpoint/step400-worker0.bin
...
```

the launch command is the same as starting a new job

```
./bin/singa-run.sh -conf=...
```
Please re-create data shards for mnist and cifar10 examples, as the protocol buffer message for Record has been changed.

```
nworker_groups: 2
nserver_groups: 2
```

Each server group serves one worker group. One worker group and one server group will be created in one processes (two processes will be launched in total).

Would you please rephrase the commit message format? (you can do it by git rebase -i and git push -f)
We are following the format like 

```
SINGA-xx  Miscellaneous minor bug fixes
BLANK LINE
commit message content
```

The SINGA-xx is the jira ticket number.https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SINGA
Thanks a lot.
Thanks!

Currently SINGA uses glog for logging.
Hence InitGoogleLogging must be called.
We put it into driver::Init(), therefore users do not need to call google::Init.. explicitly.

I think if SINGA does not depend on glog, then we can remove it from driver::init. Users call google::Init .. if they use glog in their code. 

Doe it make sense?

The thing is, if multiple libraries use glog and each library calls google::InitGoogleLogging, then it becomes impossible to use these libraries together. Personally, I don't like the way glog forces program termination when google::InitGoogleLogging is called multiple. However, without a public API allowing the user to query whether glog has been initialized, the next best course is for all the library writers to cooperate and not call google::InitGoogleLogging inside the library.
By the way, glog does function without a call to google::InitGoogleLogging. In this case, a warning message is printed during the first use of glog without initialization, and all logs just go to stderr without colour.
Thanks again for accepting the pull request. :)

Hi, would you please re-send the pull request with a clean commit based on the latest master branch.
It seems that you merged one old branch with the latest master and then worked on it.

It would be better to follow this work flow
1. checkout the latest master branch to a new branch
2. do the update on the new branch, and commit
3. checkout to the master branch and pull the master from incubator-singa github
4. checkout to the new branch, rebase to the latest master branch 
5. send pull request

In function `MVAddCol` (383 line in math_blob.h), I think "`if (B.transpose())`" should be "`if (B->transpose())`" because B is a pointer type of Blob.
Maybe the same issue with `MVAddRow` (423 line).
In some situation, operation that can reduce **column** of A to an element of B is needed like the operation in `Reduce2D`. Maybe explicitly transpose operation can help.

@wangsheng1001 
1. we may need to update `singa-run.sh` and zookeeper related code to consider the special case of running on a single node.  For single node training/test, we can directly use the python code to launch the program. In other words, there is no need to launch the program via `./bin/singa-run.sh`.
2. for multi-node training, we may need to launch the program as 
   
   ./bin/singa-run.sh -exec user_main.py -conf cluster.conf
   
   The python code, i.e., user_main.py, would create the JobProto object and pass it to Driver::Train. But ./bin/singa-run.sh needs to get the cluster topology, hence we still need to pass a cluster.conf to it. The cluster.conf has the configuration for a JobProto with all other fields empty except the `cluster` field.

For multi-node training, to skip parsing other proto except cluster
we need to change "rule" of some fields in JobProto from "required" to "optional".
e.g., 
JobProto: name, neuralnet, train_one_batch, updater, train_steps
ClusterProto: workspace

@wangsheng1001 @ug93tad I think we may rename this pull request to "Add HDFSStore".
HDFSStore provides functions for reading and writing key-value tuples, which is different to KVFileStore. Hence it does not need to be compatible with KVFileStore (i.e., no need to read the file created from KVFileStore). It it similar for KVFileStore and TextFileStore, which are not compatible.

When users see "Add HDFS support" , they may expect the features as in Hadoop, i.e., uploading their own files and reading it via APIs from HDFS, 
We may support such feature later. For example, we update the KVFile with an option to read data directly from HDFS.  We can also update the TextFileStore to read data directly from HDFS. Then users can upload the files created by KVFileStore/TextFileStore locally to HDFS, and then read these files at runtime via KVFileStore and TextFileStore.

thanks for sending this pull request. here are some suggestions,
1. pls only commit the changes that are necessary for your features, e.g., many conf files should not be changed (cifar10/job.conf, cifar10/gpu.conf,...)
2. see my in-line comments.
3. after addressing the above comments, pls re-format the commit messages (using rebase to merge small commits, and add the JIRA ticket number at the beginning of the title of each commit message).

Could you pls give one example illustrating the hash collision case?
Thanks.

Let us assume that there are 2 worker groups and 2 workers per group and 1 server in 1 server group, and we separate server and worker in different processes. The original Hash(1,0,0) and Hash(0,0,2) will get the same value 2, where kServer=1 and kWorker=0.
So it seems we need to add maximum of Hash function of workers when calculating function value for server group as the offset to avoid collision.

SINGA-136 Support cuDNN v4
This was solved in SINGA-126.

Hi,
pls compile SINGA with CUDA enabled.

```
./configure --enable-cuda --with-cuda=<cuda folder path>
make
```

If you do not have GPU (or CUDA), then comment out one line in job.conf

```
#gpu: 0
```
